```{r setup, include=FALSE}
library(tidyverse)
library(ggridges)
library(patchwork)
```

## Labels, ticks

```{r labels_ticks}
#load data
weather_df = 
  rnoaa::meteo_pull_monitors(c("USW00094728", "USC00519397", "USS0023B17S"),
                      var = c("PRCP", "TMIN", "TMAX"), 
                      date_min = "2017-01-01",
                      date_max = "2017-12-31") %>%
  mutate(
    name = recode(id, USW00094728 = "CentralPark_NY", 
                      USC00519397 = "Waikiki_HA",
                      USS0023B17S = "Waterhole_WA"),
    tmin = tmin / 10,
    tmax = tmax / 10) %>%
  select(name, id, everything())
weather_df

#basic plot
ggplot(weather_df, aes(x = tmin, y = tmax)) + 
  geom_point(aes(color = name), alpha = .5)

#plot with title and axes labels
ggplot(weather_df, aes(x = tmin, y = tmax)) + 
  geom_point(aes(color = name), alpha = .5) + 
  labs(
    title = "Temperature plot",
    x = "Minimum daily temperature (C)",
    y = "Maxiumum daily temperature (C)",
    caption = "Data from the rnoaa package"
  )

#plot with scale (x and y axes)
#scale can set axes ticks and labels and positions the y-axis to right
ggplot(weather_df, aes(x = tmin, y = tmax)) + 
  geom_point(aes(color = name), alpha = .5) + 
  labs(
    title = "Temperature plot",
    x = "Minimum daily temperature (C)",
    y = "Maxiumum daily temperature (C)",
    caption = "Data from the rnoaa package"
  ) + 
  scale_x_continuous(breaks = c(-15, 0, 15), 
                     labels = c("-15ÂºC", "0", "15"),
                     limits = c(-20, 30)) + 
  scale_y_continuous(trans = "sqrt", 
                     position = "right")

```
## Colors and themes

```{r colors}
#hues is range of hues. this method is not recommended because you're creating your own color palette
ggplot(weather_df, aes(x = tmin, y = tmax)) + 
  geom_point(aes(color = name), alpha = .5) + 
  labs(
    title = "Temperature plot",
    x = "Minimum daily temperature (C)",
    y = "Maxiumum daily temperature (C)",
    caption = "Data from the rnoaa package"
  ) + 
  scale_color_hue(name = "Location", 
                  h = c(100, 300))

#viridis is recommended. built in color palettes
#discrete = true means don't give continuous color scale, but 3 different colors
ggplot(weather_df, aes(x = tmin, y = tmax)) + 
  geom_point(aes(color = name), alpha = .5) + 
  labs(
    title = "Temperature plot",
    x = "Minimum daily temperature (C)",
    y = "Maxiumum daily temperature (C)",
    caption = "Data from the rnoaa package"
  ) + 
  viridis::scale_color_viridis(
    name = "Location", 
    discrete = TRUE
  )

#legend placement. Here it is placed on bottom
ggplot(weather_df, aes(x = tmin, y = tmax)) + 
  geom_point(aes(color = name), alpha = .5) + 
  labs(
    title = "Temperature plot",
    x = "Minimum daily temperature (C)",
    y = "Maxiumum daily temperature (C)",
    caption = "Data from the rnoaa package"
  ) + 
  viridis::scale_color_viridis(
    name = "Location", 
    discrete = TRUE
  ) + 
  theme(legend.position = "bottom")

#changing theme to black and white (bw)
ggplot(weather_df, aes(x = tmin, y = tmax)) + 
  geom_point(aes(color = name), alpha = .5) + 
  labs(
    title = "Temperature plot",
    x = "Minimum daily temperature (C)",
    y = "Maxiumum daily temperature (C)",
    caption = "Data from the rnoaa package"
  ) + 
  viridis::scale_color_viridis(
    name = "Location", 
    discrete = TRUE
  ) + 
  theme_bw() + 
  theme(legend.position = "bottom")

#changing theme to blank (classic)
ggplot(weather_df, aes(x = tmin, y = tmax)) + 
  geom_point(aes(color = name), alpha = .5) + 
  labs(
    title = "Temperature plot",
    x = "Minimum daily temperature (C)",
    y = "Maxiumum daily temperature (C)",
    caption = "Data from the rnoaa package"
  ) + 
  viridis::scale_color_viridis(
    name = "Location", 
    discrete = TRUE
  ) + 
  theme_classic() + 
  theme(legend.position = "bottom")

#excel theme with ggthemes
ggplot(weather_df, aes(x = tmin, y = tmax)) + 
  geom_point(aes(color = name), alpha = .5) + 
  labs(
    title = "Temperature plot",
    x = "Minimum daily temperature (C)",
    y = "Maxiumum daily temperature (C)",
    caption = "Data from the rnoaa package"
  ) + 
  viridis::scale_color_viridis(
    name = "Location", 
    discrete = TRUE
  ) + 
  ggthemes::theme_excel() + 
  theme(legend.position = "bottom")

#setting option 
knitr::opts_chunk$set(
  fig.width = 6,
  fig.asp = .6,
  out.width = "90%"
)

theme_set(theme_bw() + theme(legend.position = "bottom"))
```

## data argument in geom_*

```{r}
#adds new geom (geom_line) that makes central park into lines. 
central_park = 
  weather_df %>% 
  filter(name == "CentralPark_NY")

waikiki = 
  weather_df %>% 
  filter(name == "Waikiki_HA")

ggplot(waikiki, aes(x = date, y = tmax, color = name)) + 
  geom_point() + 
  geom_line(data = central_park)
```
## Patchwork

```{r}
#create panels of plots together in one graphic. Create each panel/plot individually and then stitch then together. The last line shows their orientation.
tmax_tmin_p = ggplot(weather_df, aes(x = tmax, y = tmin, color = name)) + 
  geom_point(alpha = .5) +
  theme(legend.position = "none")

prcp_dens_p = weather_df %>% 
  filter(prcp > 0) %>% 
  ggplot(aes(x = prcp, fill = name)) + 
  geom_density(alpha = .5) + 
  theme(legend.position = "none")

tmax_date_p = ggplot(weather_df, aes(x = date, y = tmax, color = name)) + 
  geom_point(alpha = .5) +
  geom_smooth(se = FALSE) + 
  theme(legend.position = "bottom")

(tmax_tmin_p + prcp_dens_p) / tmax_date_p
```

## Data manipulation

```{r}
#reorders the names manually. Since these names are factors, we have to use forcats to reorder the factor level
weather_df %>%
  mutate(name = forcats::fct_relevel(name, c("Waikiki_HA", "CentralPark_NY", "Waterhole_WA"))) %>% 
  ggplot(aes(x = name, y = tmax)) + 
  geom_violin(aes(fill = name), color = "blue", alpha = .5) + 
  theme(legend.position = "bottom")

#reorders names based on tmax
weather_df %>%
  mutate(name = forcats::fct_reorder(name, tmax)) %>% 
  ggplot(aes(x = name, y = tmax)) + 
  geom_violin(aes(fill = name), color = "blue", alpha = .5) + 
  theme(legend.position = "bottom")

#tidying data before data is formatted in a way to plot
weather_df %>%
  select(name, tmax, tmin) %>% 
  gather(key = observation, value = temp, tmax:tmin) %>% 
  ggplot(aes(x = temp, fill = observation)) +
  geom_density(alpha = .5) + 
  facet_grid(~name) + 
  viridis::scale_fill_viridis(discrete = TRUE)
```
